summary:
I am a recent graduate from USC Keck School of Medicine where I received my M.S. in Stem Cell Biology and Regenerative Medicine. In May 2023, I received a B.S. in Human Biology with Honors from USC with a double minor in Health Care Studies and Science and Management of Biomedical Therapeutics. I am committed to making a meaningful impact in the biotech industry by utilizing my skillsets and experience to contribute to healthcare advancement.

Please contact me at cmchung0@gmail.com for potential collaborations or opportunities.

currentPositions.description:
Overseeing operations for the Research and Development division of Nexabio Venture Solutions, a biotech startup aimed at providing consulting services, advancements in data engineering, discovery biology research, and improvements to bio-system datasets. 
• Spearhead operations and lead the Research and Development division in developing novel drug and cell modeling therapeutics, resulting in the initiation and ongoing growth of 3 projects.
   o Review Article/Meta-Analysis for Preliminary Research in Profiling Diseases, Mathematical Modeling, and Biophysical Equations for Predictive Models
   o Analysis of Protein Structure Based on Disease Outcomes to Establish Protein Interactions and Characteristics
   o Development of Computational Cell Lines and Computational Drug Models for Predictive Studies 
• Develop computational systems in Python and C++ integrating mathematical models, biophysical equations, and academic data collected from internal literature reviews. 
• Facilitate the onboarding procedures for new employees/interns and oversee the training process of research protocols and pipelines.
currentPositions.title: Chief Scientific Officer

publications.description: Abstract (selected words): Here, we build a parameterized computational framework that, given a cell-cell communication network driving changes in cell adhesion and initial conditions as inputs, predicts developmental trajectories. We first built a general computational framework where contact-dependent cell-cell signaling networks and changes in cell-cell adhesion could be designed in a modular fashion. We then used a set of available in vitro results (that we call the "training set" in analogy to similar pipelines in the machine learning field) to parameterize the computational model with values for adhesion and signaling. We then show that this parameterized model can qualitatively predict experimental results from a "testing set" of available in vitro data that varied the genetic network in terms of adhesion combinations, initial number of cells, and even changes to the network architecture. Finally, this parameterized model is used to recommend novel network implementation for the formation of a four-layered structure that has not been reported previously. The framework that we develop here could function as a testing ground to identify the reachable space of morphologies that can be obtained by controlling contact-dependent cell-cell communications and adhesion with these molecular tools and in this cellular system. Additionally, we discuss how the model could be expanded to include other forms of communication or effectors for the computational design of the next generation of synthetic developmental trajectories.
publications.name: Parameterized Computational Framework for the Description and Design of Genetic Circuits of Morphogenesis Based on Contact-Dependent Signaling and Changes in Cell–Cell Adhesion

publications.description:
Undergraduate Thesis for Bachelor of Science in Human Biology with Honors 

Abstract
Synthetic morphogenesis aims to program the self-organization of multicellular tissues in specific patterns and shapes through the use of synthetic genetic circuits. While efforts in the field have succeeded in achieving the programming of specific spatial patterns, a current frontier is the programming of tissue shape change. One of the current goals of the lab is to reach this milestone by programming tissue elongation. For that, the lab has designed a blueprint for programming elongation through the spatiotemporal control of tissue growth and viscosity. In this work, we advanced this project through two complementary approaches: 1) an in silico modeling approach to design and analyze the robustness of candidate genetic circuits and 2) a collection of in vitro experimental paradigms to develop and troubleshoot the different modules required for this strategy.

In this work, we report progress in the development of three modules required for programming synthetic elongation in vitro: proliferation control, tissue fluidity control, and spatiotemporal fate propagation control. We then used those results to parametrize an in silico model of multicellular systems previously developed by the lab in the CompuCell3D framework to simulate synthetic gene circuits and engineered cell-cell communication. Using the parametrized model, we identified better control of tissue growth rate as a priority target on which to concentrate in vitro efforts.

In conclusion, we demonstrated methods for parametrizing critical aspects of any multicellular tissue in silico models. We then used those methods to inform our cell engineering efforts, optimizing the efficiency of our development of a new synthetic gene regulatory network to program tissue shape change.
publications.name: Programming Multicellular Self-Organization of Mammalian Cells: in silico Modeling and in vitro Implementation

publications.description: OBJECTIVES: To understand how energy drinks are marketed and regulated and the effects of these policies on adolescent consumption and perceptions of the product. METHODS: A review of research studies using the PubMed database; clinical trials (clinicaltrials.gov); FDA Recall, Market Withdrawals, and Safety Alerts (FDA.gov); and emergency department (ED) visits from reports from the Drug Abuse Warning Network were conducted. A survey will be sent to undergraduate/graduate university students through advertised QR codes and university email chains sent out to student organizations/courses. The survey will determine the percentage of respondents who consume caffeine, the frequency in which individuals consume caffeine, and reasons for consuming caffeine. The survey also seeks to understand perceptions on energy drinks and caffeine regulation and consumption. RESULTS: From January 1st, 2000, to August 5th, 2022, 112 research studies investigated the physiological impact of energy drinks on adolescents, and 13 clinical trials from the age group of 0-17 were conducted. No FDA recalls have been observed for energy drinks or the top 4 brands within the US (by sales; Red Bull, Monster, Bang Energy, Rockstar), though some recalls regarding container manufacturing were made outside the US. ED visits from energy drinks doubled from 2007 to 2011 with 1/10 of them resulting in hospitalization. 58% of the total ED visits were exclusively related to energy drinks. It is anticipated that survey results will indicate trends of frequent caffeine/energy drink consumption among college students for studying, but students will not have a clear understanding of recommended caffeine intake. DISCUSSION: Due to the lack of regulations and studies surrounding energy drinks, the dangers to public health are concerning. Regulatory agencies should invest in developing new regulations regarding the content of energy drinks and monitor the marketing strategies more closely behind them.
publications.name: Regulations and Marketing of Energy Drinks in the United States: A Survey of University Student Beliefs about Caffeine Consumption
publications.publisher: Journal of Clinical and Translational Science/Cambridge University Press

publications.description: (PREPRINT) This review rigorously investigates the evolving pharmacological landscape for metabolic disorders, focusing on Phenylketonuria (PKU), Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD), Galactosemia, Medium Chain Acyl CoA Dehydrogenase Deficiency (MCADD), and Prader-Willi Syndrome (PWS). Adhering to PRISMA guidelines, we meticulously searched databases such as NHS, Rare Diseases, Pubchem, Clinical Trials, DrugBank, PubMed, and Mayo Clinic, spanning from January 2000 to December 2023. Our objective was to evaluate the efficacy and potential of both FDA-approved drugs and those in clinical trials. The review revealed significant advancements in the treatment of disorders like PKU, with drugs like Kuvan facilitating improved metabolic functioning. In IBD, treatments have progressed to specifically target inflammatory pathways using drugs like Azathioprine and Mesalazine, shifting away from broader immunosuppressants. Galactosemia and MCADD, disorders without definitive cures, have shown potential in clinical trials with investigational drugs like AT-007 and Triheptanoin. Particularly intriguing are the ongoing trials for PWS, a complex syndrome, where Oral NNZ-2591 and Oxytocin demonstrate promising potential. These findings highlight the critical importance of specialized treatment strategies, tailored to address the unique metabolic challenges posed by each disorder. The diverse nature of these disorders necessitates a multifaceted approach, combining current scientific knowledge with innovative drug development. This study not only contributes to a better understanding of existing treatments but also emphasizes the need for continued research and development to uncover more effective and personalized therapeutic options for managing these varied metabolic disorders.
publications.name: An Analysis of Metabolic Conditions and Current Therapeutic Approaches: A Systematic Review

publications.description: (PREPRINT) Antibody-drug conjugates (ADCs), a groundbreaking advancement in cancer therapy, synergistically combine the precision of monoclonal antibodies with the potent destruction capabilities of cytotoxic drugs, signifying a new era in the targeted oncological treatments. This comprehensive paper delves into the evolving field of antibody-drug conjugates (ADCs) and their pivotal role in cancer therapy. We have conducted an in-depth exploration of the structural components of ADCs, including target antigens, monoclonal antibodies, chemical linkers, and cytotoxic payloads, each playing a crucial role in determining the efficacy and safety profile of these novel therapies. A detailed market analysis reveals the leading pharmaceutical companies shaping the ADC landscape, reflecting the growing interest and potential in this therapeutic approach. We further dissect the engineering intricacies of ADCs, focusing on their ability to target specific cancer cell antigens while minimizing off-target effects, thus offering a more focused treatment with reduced systemic side effects compared to traditional chemotherapy. This approach holds promise in a heightened therapeutic index and decreased toxicity. The mechanisms and effector functions of ADCs are explored, highlight- ing their multifaceted strategy in combating cancer. We include a comprehensive look at how ADCs operate from initial blood circulation to the induction of apoptosis in cancer cells. We also review several key ADCs currently in use or under investigation, offering insights into their unique mechanisms of action, pharmacokinetics, and clinical implications. The discussion extends to drug creation modalities, focusing on innovative conjugation techniques that enhance ADC homogeneity and therapeutic efficacy. In conclusion, the paper underscores the transformative potential of ADCs in the realm of cancer treatment, marking a shift towards more precise and targeted therapeutic approaches.
publications.name: Revolutionizing Cancer Treatment - The Emergence and Impact of Antibody-Drug Conjugates (ADCs): A Systematic Review

publications.description: (PREPRINT) With a growing market size, and a large variety of applications, monoclonal antibody technology adoption and clinical usage is at an all-time high. This review article seeks to explore 10 monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) and their mechanism of action, specifically their pharmacodynamic (PD) and pharmacokinetic (PK) properties, and use a machine learning model with various parameters to assess whether the mAb has adequate bioavailability when delivered subcutaneously. This is an investigation of drug optimization and patient outcomes when transitioning from traditional IV administrations to subcutaneous injections. The machine learning model is an extension based on a paper by Han Lou and Michael Hageman, Machine Learning Attempts for Predicting Human Subcutaneous Bioavailability of Monoclonal Antibodies, where they took 10 mAbs and analyzed 45 different features. To further extend this paper, we took an additional 10 monoclonal antibodies that were delivered subcutaneously, and took into account their dosage concentration as an extension to traditional PK properties. By including additional mAbs and dosage, a more sophisticated model can be produced with high scalability to deep learning modalities.
publications.name: Potential Opportunities of Modeling Bioavailability for Monoclonal Antibodies: An Overview of mAbs and the current challenges of mAb development

message.text:
Make Diagrams from generative AI 

It doesn't seem to be possible to generate useful diagrams directly from the chat interface.  

The following 2 diagrams were made with chatGPT4 and claude-3-opus with the prompt "Make a concept map using subgraphs in mermaid js to explain mechanisms of ige mediated allergy".

This uses a tool called mermaid js to generate structured text that can be pasted into a live editor at https://mermaid.live to create an diagram. 

Sometimes it will work straight away, but often times you will need to paste in the error messages back into chat a few times to get it to work

this mermaid code can be put back into the free diagram editor drawio:


Mabey could upload a word doc or powerpoint presentation to make it more diagrammy...

ingestedContentSummary.description: Simplify documentation and avoid heavy tools. Open source Visio Alternative. Commonly used for explaining your code! Mermaid is a simple markdown-like script language for generating charts from text via javascript.
ingestedContentSummary.title: Online FlowChart & Diagrams Editor - Mermaid Live Editor

message.text: I like the idea of making diagrams from text - here is my attempt at a template for driver diagrams https://lnkd.in/esyTu-Ur

Omar Yunus my brother in law has been working on a project that uses technology to create the best sadaqat jahriya model (continuous charity) available. So far, his project has been able to make one donation generate 33x more impact than a traditional donation over the course of an average lifetime. You can check it out at Afterfund.co.

I thought I knew everything about being an armed forces spouse - the mobility - 8 schools for our girls - the deployment - 6 tours of Afghanistan - abandoning my career to take piece meal jobs.  Months and years apart for the duration of the Afghan conflict.  Until 3 years ago on this day 8 March 2021, my husband of 17 years, Colonel Nick Carrell, died from a rapid and aggressive form of brain cancer, whilst still serving.

It was then I realised that I didn’t know everything about being an army spouse. I didn’t know that we had 93 days to vacate our home, that my children would soon become ineligible for their eductional bursaries, that my VO would be permitted to support my devastated little family for just six weeks, as they had other more important things for her to do elsewhere ..

I learned that after two weeks, no one from the MoD calls, that they think when they’re handed you a purple pack and an indecent pension that they have “extracted from the bereaved family as clinically as possible “ , their words not  mine.  I learned that no one talks about transition for the spouse or breakfast clubs or drop ins. And for our bereaved children they lose their home, their school, their identity and their parent. 

We had to leave the community we’d lived in for almost 2 decades - were we still armed forces ? No, we’re not serving. Were we veterans ? No we never served.

So who are we ? We’re adrift and so are so many other military bereaved families.

I am working to change the narrative around our military bereaved, to bring together the families, the MoD, the armed forces charity sector, the NHS and other support pathways because we must do better for families who have lost their loved ones whilst serving this country .

This was our last homecoming. Nick had been in Kabul for 8 months with no R&R.

Please help me to spread the word to help raise awareness in galvanising better support to the military bereaved community and in bringing about systemic change in the space that the armed forces community gives to families like mine.  Thanks for reading. 

#mIlitarywives #militaryspouses #armywife #armywidow #militarywidow #warwidow #bereavedfamilies #childhoodbereavement #forceschilden #bereavedmilitarychildren

commentary.text:
Omar Yunus thanks Omar!  This is a specific kind of diagram called a driver diagram which is popular in health quality improvement planning.  

There is a way of generating such diagrams from text using generative ai but it can be a bit flaky and a 2 step process I might post on it
